an6.54:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
an6.54:4.2: Now at that time Venerable Dhammika was a resident in all seven monasteries of his native land.
an6.54:4.3: There he abused visiting mendicants; he insulted, harmed, attacked, and harassed them.
an6.54:4.4: The visiting mendicants who were treated in this way did not stay. They left abandoning the monastery.
an6.54:5.1: Then the local lay followers thought to themselves:
an6.54:5.2: “We have supplied the mendicant Saṅgha with robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
an6.54:5.3: But the visiting mendicants don’t stay. They leave abandoning the monastery.
an6.54:5.4: What is the cause, what is the reason for this?”
an6.54:5.5: Then the local lay followers thought to themselves:
an6.54:5.6: “This Venerable Dhammika abuses visiting mendicants; he insults, harms, attacks, and harasses them.
an6.54:5.7: The visiting mendicants who were treated in this way do not stay. They leave abandoning the monastery.
an6.54:5.8: Why don’t we banish Venerable Dhammika?”

an6.54:10.1: Then Venerable Dhammika took his bowl and robes and set out for Rājagaha.
an6.54:10.2: Eventually he came to Rājagaha and the Vulture’s Peak. He went up to the Buddha,
an6.54:10.3: bowed, and sat down to one side.
an6.54:10.5: “So, Brahmin Dhammika, where have you come from?”
an6.54:10.6: “Sir, I’ve been banished by the local lay followers from all seven monasteries in my native land.”
an6.54:10.7: “Enough, Brahmin Dhammika, what’s that to you? Now that you’ve been banished from all of those places, you have come to me.
an6.54:11.1: Once upon a time, some sea-merchants set sail for the ocean deeps, taking with them a land-spotting bird.
an6.54:11.2: When their ship was out of sight of land, they released the bird.
an6.54:11.3: It flew right away to the east, the west, the north, the south, upwards, and in-between.
an6.54:11.4: If it saw land in any direction it flew straight there.
an6.54:11.5: But if it saw no land it returned to the ship.
an6.54:11.6: In the same way, now that you’ve been banished from all of those places, you have come to me.

an6.54:12.2: Its canopy spread over twelve leagues, while the network of roots spread for five leagues.

an6.54:12.7: The king and harem made use of one trunk, the troops another, the people of town and country another, ascetics and brahmins another, and beasts and birds another.
an6.54:12.8: No-one guarded the fruit, yet no-one damaged another’s fruits.
an6.54:13.1: Then a certain person ate as much as he liked of the fruit, then broke off a branch and left.
an6.54:13.2: Then the god haunting the royal banyan tree thought:
an6.54:13.4: How wicked this person is, to eat as much as they like, then break off a branch and leave! Why don’t I make sure that the royal banyan tree gives no fruit in future?”
an6.54:13.5: Then the royal banyan tree gave no more fruit.
an6.54:14.1: Then King Koravya went up to Sakka, the Lord of Gods,
an6.54:14.3: ‘Please sir, you should know that the royal banyan tree called Well Planted gives no fruit.’
an6.54:14.4: Then Sakka used his psychic powers to will that a violent storm come. And it felled and uprooted the royal banyan tree.
an6.54:14.5: Then the god haunting the tree stood to one side, miserable and sad, weeping, with a tearful face.
an6.54:15.1: Then Sakka went up to that god,
an6.54:15.3: ‘Why, god, are you standing to one side, miserable and sad, weeping, with a tearful face?’
an6.54:15.4: ‘Because, my good sir, a violent storm came and felled and uprooted my home.’
an6.54:15.5: ‘Well, did you stand by your tree’s duty when the storm came?’
an6.54:15.6: ‘But how, my good sir, does a tree stand by its duty?’
an6.54:15.7: ‘It’s when those who need the tree’s roots, bark, leaves, flowers or fruit take what they need.
an6.54:15.8: Yet the god is not displeased or upset or upset because of this.
an6.54:15.9: This is how a tree stands by its duty.’
an6.54:15.10: ‘I was not standing by a tree’s duty when the storm came and felled and uprooted my home.’
an6.54:15.11: ‘God, if you were to stand by a tree’s duty, your home may be as it was before.’
an6.54:15.12: ‘I will stand by a tree’s duty! May my home be as it was before!’
an6.54:16.1: Then Sakka used his psychic powers to will that a violent storm come. And it raised up that mighty banyan tree and the bark of the roots was healed.
an6.54:16.2: In the same way, Brahmin Dhammika, were you doing an ascetic’s duty when the local lay followers banished you from all seven of the monasteries in your native land?”
an6.54:16.3: “But sir, how do I stand by an ascetic’s duty?”
an6.54:16.4: “When someone abuses, annoys, or argues with an ascetic, the ascetic doesn’t abuse, annoy, or argue back at them.
an6.54:16.5: That’s how an ascetic stands by an ascetic’s duty.”
an6.54:16.6: “I was not standing by an ascetic’s duty when the local lay followers banished me from all seven of the monasteries in my native land.”
an6.54:17.1: “Once upon a time, there was a Teacher called Sunetta. He was a religious founder and was free of sensual desire.
an6.54:17.2: He had many hundreds of disciples.
an6.54:17.3: He taught them the way to rebirth in the company of Brahmā.
an6.54:17.4: Those lacking confidence in Sunetta were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an6.54:17.5: Those full of confidence in Sunetta were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an6.54:23.1: What do you think, Brahmin Dhammika? If someone with malicious intent were to abuse and insult these six teachers with their hundreds of followers, would they not make much bad karma?”
an6.54:23.4: But someone who abuses and insults a single person accomplished in view with malicious intent makes even more bad karma.
an6.54:23.6: Brahmin Dhammika, I say that outside of the Buddhist community there is no injury like that of harming one’s spiritual companions.
an6.54:23.7: So you should train like this:
an6.54:23.8: ‘We will have no malicious intent for those who we want to have as our spiritual companions.’
an6.54:23.9: That is how you should train.”
